N1.Q: What is the supreme law of the land?

N2.A:
Sets up the government 
 Protects basic rights of Americans 
 Defines the government

N3.Q: The idea of self-government is in the first three words of the Constitution. What are these words?

N5.Q: What do we call the first ten amendments to the Constitution?

N6.Q: What is one right or freedom from the First Amendment?
N6.A:
Speech 
 Religion 
 Assembly 
 Press 
 Petition the government

N7.Q: How many amendments does the Constitution have?

N8.Q: What did the Declaration of Independence do?
N8.A:
Announced our independence (from Great Britain) 
 Declared our independence (from Great Britain) 
 Said that the United States is free (from Great Britain)

N9.Q: What are two rights in the Declaration of Independence?

N10.A: You can practice any religion, or not practice religion

N11.Q: What is the economic system in the United States?

N12.A:
Everyone must follow the law. 
 Leaders must obey the law. 
 Government must obey the law. 
 No one is above the law.

N13.Q: Name one branch or part of the government?
N13.A:
Congress 
 Legislative 
 President 
 Executive 
 The court 
 Judicial

N14.Q: What stops one branch of government from becoming too powerful?
N14.A:
Seperation of Powers 
 Checks and Balances

N15.Q: Who is in charge of the executive branch?

N16.A:
Congress 
 Senate and House (of Representatives) 
 (U.S. or national) legislature

N17.Q: What are the two parts of the U.S congress?
N17.A: The Senate and House of Representatives

N22.Q: We elect a U.S. Representative for how many years?

N23.A:
Answers will vary. [Residents of territories with nonvoting Delegates or Resident 
 Commissioners may provide the name of that Delegate of Commissioner. 
 Also acceptable is any statement that the territory has no (voting) Representatives in congress.]

N24.Q: Who does a U.S. Senator represent?

N25.Q: Why do some states have more Representatives than other states?
N25.A:
The state’s population. 
 They have more people. 
 Some states have more people.

N37.A:
Reviews laws 
 Explains laws 
 Resolves disputes (disagreements) 
 Decides if a law goes against the Constitution

N41.Q: Under our Constitution, some powers belong to the federal government. What is one power of the federal government?
N41.A:
To print money 
 To declare war 
 To create an army 
 To make treaties

N42.Q: Under our Constitution, some powers belong to the states. What is one power of the states?
N42.A:
Provide schooling and education 
 Provide protection (police) 
 Provide safety (fire departments) 
 Give a driver’s license 
 Approve zoning and land use

N48.Q: There are four amendments to the Constitution about who can vote. Describe one of them.
N48.A:
Citizens eighteen (18) and older (can vote). 
 You don’t have to pay (a poll tax) to vote. 
 Any citizen can vote. (Women and men can vote.) 
 A male citizen of any race (can vote).

N49.Q: What is one responsibility that is only for United States citizens?
N49.A:
Serve on a jury 
 Vote in a federal election

N50.Q: Name one right only for United States citizens.
N50.A:
Vote in a federal election 
 Run for federal office

N51.Q: What are two rights of everyone living in the United States?
N51.A:
Freedom of expression 
 Freedom of speech

N52.Q: What do we show loyalty to when we say the Pledge of Allegiance?

N53.Q: What is one promise you make when you become a United States citizen?
N53.A:
Give up loyalty to other countries 
 Defend the Constitution and laws of the United States 
 Obey the laws of the United States

N54.Q: How old do citizens have to be to vote for President?

N55.Q: What are two ways that Americans can participate in their democracy?
N55.A:
Vote 
 Join a political party 
 Help with a campaign 
 Join a civic group 
 Join a community group

N56.Q: When is the last day you can send in federal income tax forms?

N57.Q: When must all men register for the Selective Service?
N57.A:
At age eighteen (18) 
 Between eighteen (18) and twenty-six (26)

N58.Q: What is one reason colonists came to America?

Freedom

 Religious freedom 
 Economic opportunity 
 Practice their religion 
 Escape persecution

N61.A:
because of high taxes (taxation without representation) 
 because the British army stayed in their houses (boarding, quartering) 
 because they didn’t have self-government
